title: (Not So) Guilty Pleasures: Litquake's Opening Night
description: Litquake’s opening night invites attendees to celebrate the books they’d never admit to reading. Guests are encouraged to share their guilty‑pleasure titles when buying tickets, and comedian Natasha Muse will craft a custom set based on those answers. The party features food, drinks and music from DJ Lead Teddy to launch the 2025 festival season
location: Hawthorn SF Nightclub and Lounge, 46 Geary St, San Francisco CA 94108

locationInfo.listingLocation: Hawthorn SF Nightclub and Lounge (46 Geary St, San Francisco CA 94108)

title: Bastard Out of Carolina Marathon Reading
description: Litquake presents a cover‑to‑cover marathon reading of Dorothy Allison’s debut novel ‘Bastard Out of Carolina.’  Celebrating the author’s legacy as a writer, lesbian feminist and advocate for sexual freedom, the event features readers who knew Allison as well as theatre groups including Crowded Fire Theater, Poltergeist Theatre Project and Word for Word. Artistic direction by Sean Owens and Hyazinth Baumann from Fancypants Productions. The event is free with a $10–15 suggested donation
location: Arion Press, Landmark Building B, 2 Marina Blvd Suite 100, San Francisco, CA 94123
address: Landmark Building B, 2 Marina Blvd Suite 100, San Francisco, CA 94123

locationInfo.listingLocation: Arion Press (Landmark Building B, 2 Marina Blvd Suite 100, San Francisco, CA 94123)
locationInfo.address: Landmark Building B, 2 Marina Blvd Suite 100, San Francisco, CA 94123

title: Writers Weekend: Stories from the Inside
description: Creative writing and literary arts are powerful tools for healing and restorative justice.  Facilitators and former participants of creative‑writing prison programs discuss how writing, poetry and storytelling help individuals heal, restore and find purpose. Panelists include Sam Bhatia, Bleu Inkk Watkins, Rahsaan ‘New York’ Thomas, Zoe Mullery, Raheem Ballard and Emile Suotonye DeWeaver; moderated by Reka Barton. Pay what you can to guarantee a seat; free to walk‑ups space depending
location: California College of the Arts, 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco
cost: Pay what you can; free to walk‑ups
address: 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco

title: Spotting Opportunities: A Conversation with Filmmakers
description: Author Kevin Smokler moderates a panel with Bay Area filmmaker Tiffany Shlain and other Mill Valley Film Festival guests. They explore how filmmakers identify opportunities and transform inspiration into tangible projects. Topics include spotting inspiration, identifying worthwhile opportunities, finding creative collaborators, financing, time management, community partners and showcasing completed films. The event is free
location: Outdoor Art Club, 1 W Blithedale Ave, Mill Valley

locationInfo.listingLocation: Outdoor Art Club (1 W Blithedale Ave, Mill Valley)

title: Writers Weekend: Fostering Empathy Through Nonfiction
description: Four nonfiction authors discuss how their reporting and narrative writing humanize complex issues such as homelessness, migration, drug‑fueled violence and the opioid crisis. Moderated by Tom Barbash, the panel demonstrates how clear and empathetic storytelling fosters understanding. Pay what you can to guarantee a seat; free to walk‑ups
location: California College of the Arts, 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco
cost: Pay what you can; free to walk‑ups
address: 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco

title: The Fantasy and Necessity of Solidarity: A Tenderloin Workshop
description: Writer and cultural critic Sarah Schulman discusses the complexities of solidarity with oppressed communities. She invites attendees and Tenderloin neighborhood organizations to join an informal workshop exploring solidarity and its importance. The event features a performance by Skywatchers and is moderated by 48 Hills editor Marke Bieschke. Doors open at 2:30 pm; masks are required. Free with a $10–15 suggested donation

title: Writers Weekend: Practices for Compassionate Creatives
description: Author Mitali Perkins leads a workshop based on her book ‘Just Making: A Guide for Compassionate Creatives.’ She shares five practices to help writers and artists persevere in creating work that promotes justice amid a chaotic world. Pay what you can to guarantee a seat; free to walk‑ups
location: California College of the Arts, 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco
cost: Pay what you can; free to walk‑ups
address: 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco

locationInfo.address: 145 Hooper St., Room N‑203, Simpson Family Galleries Building, San Francisco

title: Disaster, with a Side of Noodles
description: Lambda Award winner Lee Lai discusses her graphic novel ‘Cannon’ about a restaurant worker who rebuilds her life after a crisis. Science‑fiction writer Annalee Newitz talks about ‘Automatic Noodle,’ a dystopian tale where four robots open an underground restaurant. Moderator Soleil Ho leads the conversation about resilience, identity and making the best of bad situations through food and friendship. Free event with a $10–15 suggested donation
location: Mrs. Dalloway's, 2904 College Ave, Berkeley, CA

locationInfo.listingLocation: Mrs. Dalloway's (2904 College Ave, Berkeley, CA)

title: Gilded Rage—Elon Musk and the Radicalization of Silicon Valley
description: Financial reporter Jacob Silverman discusses his book ‘Gilded Rage,’ which examines Silicon Valley’s rightward turn and how figures like Elon Musk exemplify this shift. He and Alex Hanna of the Distributed AI Research Institute explore political influence, deregulation and the lure of technofascism. Doors open at 6:30 pm. Tickets are $10 in advance ($5 limited time) or $15 at the door
location: Gray Area / Grand Theater, 2665 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94110

locationInfo.listingLocation: Gray Area / Grand Theater (2665 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94110, USA)

title: Books Not Bans presents: The Transformative Power of Fiction
description: This panel explores how reading fiction increases empathy, connectedness and resilience. It features Charlie Jane Anders, Kate Folk, Elena Darling‑Hammond and others, and is moderated by Books Not Bans founder Becka Robbins. The session highlights the impact of fiction on individuals and communities and supports the Books Not Bans program, which sends queer and banned books to those who need them. Free event with a $10–15 suggested donation
location: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium, 100 Larkin St, San Francisco, CA 94102
venue: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium

locationInfo.listingLocation: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium (100 Larkin St, San Francisco, CA 94102, USA)
locationInfo.venue: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium

title: Minor Black Figures: Brandon Taylor
description: Booker Prize finalist Brandon Taylor discusses his novel ‘Minor Black Figures,’ a tender portrait of friendship, creativity and the compromises artists make. The story follows Wyeth, a Black painter navigating the New York art scene, and his friendship with Keating, a white former seminarian. Taylor is in conversation with author Jonathan Escoffery. Doors open at 7:00 pm. Tickets are $12 in advance ($6 limited time) or $15 at the door
location: David Brower Center, Goldman Theater, 2150 Allston Way, Berkeley, CA

locationInfo.listingLocation: David Brower Center, Goldman Theater (2150 Allston Way, Berkeley)

title: Men in Love, 1850s–1950s: A Visual Conversation
description: Authors and collectors Hugh Nini and Neal Treadwell present ‘Loving II: More Photographic History of Men in Love, 1850s–1950s.’ The follow‑up to their acclaimed book ‘Loving’ features over three hundred vernacular photographs that capture romantic moments between men across a century. The slideshow, audience Q&A and book signing highlight the power of love and the courage to express it. Free event with a $10–15 suggested donation
location: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium, 100 Larkin St, San Francisco, CA 94102
venue: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium

locationInfo.listingLocation: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium (100 Larkin St, San Francisco, CA 94102, USA)
locationInfo.venue: San Francisco Public Library Koret Auditorium

title: Introducing The Approach
description: This event launches a guerrilla newspaper called ‘The Approach,’ which blends newspaper, literary magazine and organizing pamphlet to help readers thwart and survive autocracy. Contributors include Ingrid Rojas Contreras, Alexis Madrigal, Lauren Markham, Rebecca Solnit, Omar El Akkad and R.O. Kwon. Held in collaboration with City Lights Booksellers & Publishers, the evening celebrates writing that navigates political emergencies. Free event with a $10–15 suggested donation
location: City Lights Booksellers & Publishers, 261 Columbus Ave, San Francisco, CA 94133

locationInfo.listingLocation: City Lights Booksellers & Publishers (261 Columbus Ave, San Francisco, CA 94133, USA)

title: Listen To Your Elders: An Elder Project Get‑Together & Reading
description: Litquake’s Elder Project brings creative writing and storytelling workshops to retirement communities in San Francisco and Oakland. Seniors participate in reading, storytelling, hands‑on writing and sharing sessions. This gathering features participants’ words and stories, inviting attendees to listen to elders. Light refreshments will be provided. The event streams on YouTube for those who cannot attend. Free with a $10–15 suggested donation

title: World Food Day: The Stories of Our Everyday Ingredients
description: Food writers, cookbook authors and local chefs share the origins of their favorite ingredients to celebrate World Food Day. Panelists Nandita Godbole, Linda Tay Esposito and Sara Calvosa Olson discuss the history of ingredients and how they reflect heritage, culture and home countries. Audience members can touch, smell and taste ingredients displayed on an exploration table. Moderated by Cecilia Phillips of KQED’s Check Please! Doors open at 5:30 pm. Tickets are $5 for Mechanics’ Institute members and $15 for the public
location: Mechanics' Institute Library, 57 Post St, San Francisco, CA 94104

locationInfo.listingLocation: Mechanics' Institute Library (57 Post St, San Francisco, CA 94104, USA)

title: The Night Trembles: Nadia Terranova with Sara Marinelli
description: Award‑winning author Nadia Terranova discusses her novel ‘The Night Trembles,’ which intertwines stories set after the 1908 earthquake in Sicily and Calabria. The book follows a young woman who seizes a chance to avoid an arranged marriage and a boy escaping his mother’s influence. Terranova converses with USF writing professor Sara Marinelli. Doors open at 6:00 pm. Free event
location: Italian Cultural Institute of San Francisco, 710 Sansome Street, San Francisco, CA 94111
venue: Italian Cultural Institute of San Francisco

locationInfo.listingLocation: Italian Cultural Institute of San Francisco (710 Sansome Street, San Francisco, CA 94111)
locationInfo.venue: Italian Cultural Institute of San Francisco

title: San Francisco Moby‑Dick Marathon 2025 (Cancelled)
description: This cover‑to‑cover reading of Herman Melville’s ‘Moby‑Dick’ has been cancelled due to the U.S. federal government shutdown. The annual event typically features volunteer readers, special guest stars and a whirlwind of performance, art and spectacle, running nonstop from noon on October 18 to noon on October 19. It is co‑presented with the San Francisco Maritime National Park Association and is free without RSVP
location: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, 900 Beach St, San Francisco
venue: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park

locationInfo.listingLocation: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park (900 Beach St, San Francisco)
locationInfo.venue: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park

title: Litquake’s Small Press Book Fair
description: This curated book fair brings together small presses and literary magazines on the Great Lawn of Yerba Buena Gardens. Enjoy a mix of poetry readings and music from the Litquake Out Loud stage while browsing tables of books and zines from local and national independent publishers
location: The Great Lawn, Yerba Buena Gardens, 700 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94103
venue: The Great Lawn, Yerba Buena Gardens

locationInfo.listingLocation: The Great Lawn, Yerba Buena Gardens (700 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94103)
